author: Cory Zurowski
title: Retired cop Sundiata Bronson continues to cost Minneapolis huge coin
text:
King looked like this after officers beat him for carrying a gun — despite having a permit. Courtesy of Zachary King When Sundiata Bronson graduated from the Minneapolis Police Department Recruit Academy in 2009, a career among those of the thin blue line represented a fresh start for the then-26-year-old. A steady paycheck in a respected profession also meant he could forget about his money woes, as evidenced by being served with two eviction notices the previous year. Two years into the job, Bronson earned the department's "Lifesaving Award," a commendation "for acts that contribute to the saving of a life." At the time, no one knew that the hero would end up being outed as a sadist who'd cost Minneapolis taxpayers more than $500,000. Early in the morning on June 18, 2012, Zachary King was walking on a downtown Minneapolis sidewalk toward his car. A handgun was tucked in a holster beneath his shirt. King had a permit to carry the weapon. A handful of Minneapolis police officers were nearby. “Hey you! What’s that bulge under your shirt?” one asked. King stopped, slowly raised both his hands, and said, “I have a conceal and carry permit. That’s my gun,” according to court records.
His MPD career spanned not even five years. However, in just the past two, the city has come to the table to settle six brutality lawsuits involving Bronson, which have cost Minneapolis almost $521,000. A seventh case is pending. Repeated messages left at Bronson's Blaine home were not returned. Bronson's life appears now to have come full circle. His financial woes from years past have been resurrected. According to Anoka County property records, his house was foreclosed upon earlier this year before being auctioned off in August.
